DOC.brief_summary: Recent data have suggested that monocyte oxidative burst defect is associated with the development of infection in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis. One report found reduced 28 day mortality in patients treated with N-acetylcysteine combined with prednisolone when compared to prednisolone alone. The current study seeks to reveal whether the mechanism by which NAC reduces susceptibility to infection is through improvement of phagocyte oxidative burst.
DOC.brief_title: N-ACetylcysteine to Reduce Infection and Mortality for Alcoholic Hepatitis
DOC.criteria: Aged 18 years or older Clinical alcoholic hepatitis: Serum bilirubin >80umol/L History of alcohol excess (>80g/day male, >60g/day female) Less than 4 weeks since admission to hospital Maddrey's discriminant function (DF) >32 Informed consent Alcohol abstinence of >6 weeks prior to randomisation Duration of jaundice >3 months Other causes of liver disease including: Evidence of viral hepatitis (hepatitis B or C) Biliary obstruction Hepatocellular carcinoma Evidence of current malignancy (except nonmelanotic skin cancer) Previous entry into the study Patients with known hypersensitivity or previous reactions to NAC Pregnant or lactating women
